raw_text:
Two Nigerian banks set to merge
 
 Nigerian banks United Bank of Africa and Standard Trust Bank have agreed plans to merge and create the biggest bank in West Africa.
 
 The deal is also in line with a 2004 directive from the Nigerian central bank that called for more consolidation in the nation's crowded banking sector. The merger was announced in a statement on Standard Trust's website on Tuesday, but no financial details were revealed. United Bank is the third biggest in Nigeria in terms of number of branches. Standard Trust is smaller but more profitable. "The boards of United Bank and Standard Trust, at separate meetings yesterday, approved arrangements to merge both institutions," Standard Trust said. Standard Trust is 100% Nigerian-owned, but United Bank has some foreign investors, including New York-based Global Depository Receipts (32.8%), and Banca Nazionale del Lavoro and Monte del Paschi di Siena, both from Italy, who each have a 2.4% stake.
llama3.2:1b: United Bank of Africa and Standard Trust Bank are to merge in West Africa, becoming the biggest bank in Nigeria. The merger is part of a 2004 directive calling for consolidation in the country's banking sector. The merged institution will be headquartered in Nigeria, with United Bank being the largest and Standard Trust being smaller but more profitable.

The two Nigerian banks, United Bank of Africa and Standard Trust Bank, have agreed to merge plans, resulting in the creation of the largest bank in West Africa. The deal aligns with a 2004 directive from the Nigerian central bank for banking consolidation. The merger was announced by Standard Trust on its website but no financial specifics were disclosed. United Bank has more branches than Standard Trust and is mostly owned by NPs, while Standard Trust holds some foreign investors, including New York-based Global Depository Receipts (32.8%) and Italian institutions, each with a 2.4% stake.
tinyllama:1.1b: Nigerian banks United Bank of Africa and Standard Trust Bank have agreed to merge and create the biggest bank in West Africa, following a directive from the Nigerian central bank in 2004. The deal is also aligned with the 2004 directive calling for more consolidation in the sector, and Standard Trust's third-largest bank, Standard Trust, will be profitably merged into United Bank. The merger was announced on a United Bank website on February 3rd, but financial details were not revealed. Both Standard Trust and United Bank are 100% Nigerian-owned, with some foreign investors including Global Depositor Receipts (32.8%) and Banca Nazionale del Lavoro from Italy, each with a 2.4% stake.
tinydolphin:1.1b:
The two Nigerian banks, United Bank of Africa (UBA) and Standard Trust Bank, are reportedly set to merge, according to a statement on their respective websites. This move is in line with the 2004 directive from the Nigerian Central Bank that called for more consolidation in the nation's crowded banking sector. As part of the merger plan, UBA will be absorbing Standard Trust and Standard Trust will subsequently join United Bank in becoming the biggest bank in West Africa.

The deal is also expected to strengthen both banks' financial positions, as they can pool their resources and capital. With the addition of Standard Trust's branches, the combined entity will have a total of approximately 400 branches across Nigeria, further solidifying its position as the third largest bank in terms of number of branches. United Bank is currently the third biggest bank with around 300 branches, while Standard Trust has around 150 branches.

The merger announcement comes a few weeks after the Nigerian central bank issued a directive in January that urged banks to consolidate their operations. The objective of this directive was to reduce competition and improve the efficiency of the financial sector in Nigeria, which is overwhelmed with numerous small banks. This move has also been seen as a step towards addressing the concerns of consumers and investors regarding banking stability, as well as the need for greater consolidation to reduce the risks associated with multiple smaller institutions.

In summary, the two Nigerian banks are in the process of merging, which is expected to lead to an increase in the number of branches of the merged entity and strengthen their financial positions.
